thread.title: Grantham flood inquiry: Witness Marty Warburton still haunted by flood’s lost souls | The
thread.title_full: Grantham flood inquiry: Witness Marty Warburton still haunted by flood’s lost souls | The Courier-Mail

author: couriermail.com.au
title: Grantham flood inquiry: Witness Marty Warburton still haunted by flood’s lost souls | The
text:
Mr Warburton, on the stand as the Grantham Flood Inquiry prepares to wind up its first week of hearing evidence in Gatton, said he felt helpless as he watched victims float past on the afternoon of January 10 2011 when a massive flood swamped Grantham.
Stuck on the roof of his service station with the roar of the water filling the air, Mr Warburton saw people crying out in terror.
One well-dressed middle aged man floated by in a car, calling him for help.
“You could just see the terror in his eyes,” Mr Warburton told Counsel Assisting Michael Hodge.
“He was just like me to you away,” “ Mr Warburton said to Mr Hodge, gesturing to the ten metre gap between them.
“You would give anything to help them but there was nothing to be done.”
Another two people on top of a car also floated down Anzac Avenue asking for help before disappearing with the car.
Mr Warburton says he still has no idea where the people are.
Mr Warburton told the inquiry a Grantham flood in past years was almost a social occasion.
The locals knew where water would rise, and at his service station people would gather and sit on milk crates and chairs.
An old surf ski would be brought out and fishing lines put in the water.
“It was always a bit of a social occasion to keep things lighthearted,” he said.
But the January 2011 event was like nothing ever experienced, he said.
Mr Warburton was eventually escorted away from the servo by a swift water team and up to high ground.
He made his way towards the school where a temporary evacuation centre was set up.
The inquiry, before Commissioner Walter Sofronoff, QC, continues.
